title: What causes opioid addiction, and why is it so tough to combat? - Mike Davis

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the flower that was used in ancient Egyptian medical texts, and from which opium is derived?
What is the name of the substance that was identified and isolated for medical use in the 19th century?
What is the term used to describe the synthetic substances similar to opiates, including heroin, hydrocodone, oxycodone, and fentanyl?
What is the primary way in which opioid drugs affect the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: By binding to opioid receptors in the brain

options.label: B
options.text: By suppressing the release of endorphins

options.label: C
options.text: By increasing the production of dopamine

options.label: D
options.text: By decreasing the production of noradrenaline

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the release of dopamine that is linked to feelings of pleasure and may be responsible for the sense of euphoria that characterizes an opioid high?
What is the term used to describe the process by which the body becomes dependent on opioids to maintain a new balance of noradrenaline?
What is the term used to describe the period of time when the body is too sensitive to noradrenaline after someone who is physically dependent on opioids stops taking them?
What is the name of the drug that is currently our best defense against overdose?
What is the term used to describe the combination of medication, health services, and psychotherapy that is used to treat opioid addiction?
What is the name of the helpline that the Department of Health and Human Services operates to provide support for people struggling with opioid use?

title: What is society? | US society for children

multiple-choice.question: What is a society?

options.label: A
options.text: A small community of people who live close to each other.

options.label: B
options.text: A large group of people who share the same laws, rights, and resources.

options.label: C
options.text: A group of people who do the same type of work.

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people who believe in the same thing.

multiple-choice.question: What can people in a society have in common?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only speak the same language.

options.label: B
options.text: They can only live in the same neighborhood.

options.label: C
options.text: They can live far away from each other and still share the same laws, rights, and resources.

options.label: D
options.text: They can only work at the same place.

multiple-choice.question: What are some examples of societies?

options.label: A
options.text: A neighborhood, a school, and a family.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A group of people who speak the same language and live in the same house.

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people who work at the same place and live in the same town.

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people who do the same type of work.

options.label: D

options.text: Soap and water, and hand sanitizer

options.text: The ability of a substance to attract water

multiple-choice.question: What is the Munker-White illusion?

options.label: A
options.text: A technique used to make colors appear different.

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon where our brains judge color and brightness in context.

options.label: C
options.text: A trick photography or editing effect.

options.label: D
options.text: A way to interpret what we see as efficiently as possible.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of our senses or eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide us with an absolute color or physical property of our external reality.

options.label: B
options.text: To interact with the environment most appropriately.

options.label: C
options.text: To interpret what we see as efficiently as possible in order to interact with the environment most appropriately.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to our perception of the tile when we remove the surrounding imagery?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes lighter than it appears.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes darker than it appears.

multiple-choice.question: What is the tile illusion taking advantage of?

options.label: A
options.text: Our brains' ability to judge color and brightness in context.

options.label: B
options.text: Our brains' ability to interpret what we see as efficiently as possible.

options.label: C
options.text: Our brains' ability to make objects look darker.

options.label: D
options.text: Our brains' ability to see shadows.

multiple-choice.question: Why does our brain compensate for the tile's appearance?

options.label: A
options.text: Because shadows make objects look darker.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the tile is lighter than it appears.

options.label: C
options.text: Because our brain is trying to interact with the environment most appropriately.

options.label: D
options.text: Because our brain is trying to interpret what we see as efficiently as possible.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to our perception of the gradient when we remove the background?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes lighter than it appears.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes darker than it appears.

multiple-choice.question: Why does our brain interpret the gradient as being darker?

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the color of the gradient.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the lightness of the gradient.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the darkness of the gradient.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the video?

options.label: A
options.text: Our brains judge color and brightness in context.

options.label: D
options.text: Our perception is influenced by our environment.

multiple-choice.question: What can be done to answer a burning question?

options.label: A
options.text: Ask it in the comments, or on Facebook and Twitter and subscribe for more weekly science videos.

options.label: C

title: 6 ways to start a sentence | Sentence structure | Learn to write

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the best ways to start a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: By explaining where or when something happens.

options.label: C
options.text: By putting the subject first and the verb second.

options.label: D
options.text: By using an action ending in ing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the subject of a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: A word that tells you what the subject is doing.

options.label: B
options.text: A person, place, thing, or idea that has to be followed by a verb.

options.label: C
options.text: A word that starts a sentence.

options.label: D
options.text: A verb that ends a sentence.

multiple-choice.question: How can you start a sentence with words that tell you where something is happening?

options.label: A
options.text: By using words such as "on the beach" or "near the beach".

options.label: B
options.text: By using words such as "after school" or "before school".

options.label: C
options.text: By using words such as "one of the best ways" or "six different ways".

options.label: D
options.text: By using words such as "looking at the clock" or "sitting on the beach".

multiple-choice.question: What makes the reader think when starting a sentence with a question?

options.label: A
options.text: A question makes the reader sleepy.

options.label: B
options.text: A question makes the reader bored.

options.label: C
options.text: A question makes the reader think.

options.label: D
options.text: A question makes the reader angry.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using a comma when starting a sentence with an action ending in ing or ed?

options.label: C
options.text: To separate the action from the rest of the sentence.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the sentence more interesting.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using an l y word to start a sentence?

options.label: C
options.text: To make the sentence more interesting.

options.label: D
options.text: To describe the subject of the sentence.
